entry.title: K-Means and Gaussian Mixture Models
entry.content:
In machine learning, clustering encompasses a family of problems and techniques for grouping unlabeled data into categories. In contrast to classification, where our job is to learn relationships between data and their associated labels, in clustering our job is to learn the labels themselves by leveraging the patterns and structure present in the data. To make this more concrete, imagine you are given two datasets containing images of cats and dogs. The datasets are identical except that in the first dataset each image comes with a label cat or dog, and in the second you only are given the image. In classification our job is to learn what features of the image are most predictive of the label (cat ears, dog nose, etc.), whereas in clustering our job is to learn how to group similar images together without any pre-existing labels. That is, to identify clusters that correspond to cat and dog based solely on the inherent features and patterns observed in the images.

The vast majority of data is unlabeled, yet the need for effective algorithmic techniques to extract meaningful information from such data is critical for its use. From the grouping of genetic sequences to identify disease patterns, to image segmentation, uses for clustering abound. In this post I introduce the problem of clustering and derive two popular techniques: KKK-means and Gaussian mixture models (GMM). To begin I will apply KKK-means to the Old Faithful dataset to give a concrete example of clustering before using the techniques shortcomings to motivate GMMs.

KKK-Means

The KKK-means algorithm is a simple and intuitive approach to clustering that doesn’t require any probability theory to understand. Suppose we are given some data set D\mathcal{D}D consisting of NNN Euclidean vectors. D={x1…xn…xN} \mathcal{D} = \{\mathbf{x}_1 \dots \mathbf{x}_n \dots \mathbf{x}_N\} D={x1​…xn​…xN​} In our example dataset each vector is 222-dimensional, but KKK-means still works in higher dimensions. Importantly, we have no other additional information. Unlike classification, we have no class labels to work with, only the raw coordinates of each data point.

Figure 1. The normalized old faithful dataset. In the unmodified data the axes represent the duration of an eruption and the time till the next eruption for the Old Faithful geyser in Yellowstone National Park.

We would like to partition the dataset above into KKK sub-groups such that each data point xn\mathbf{x}_nxn​ is associated with a unique cluster kkk. Intuitively, we would like similar data points to be clustered together and dissimilar data points to be clustered apart. It just so happens that in our dataset it is visually obvious how we should assign points to clusters, but in practice our data is rarely this nice. Our goal is essentially to categorize or classify this unlabeled data. In doing so we will depart from classification and optimize not just the boundary of the clusters, but the labels associated with each data point as well.

To begin, we’ll introduce two variables. The first is a set of KKK vectors {μ1,…,μK}\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_1, \dots, \boldsymbol{\mu}_K\}{μ1​,…,μK​} where μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ is the centroid or prototype of the kthk^{th}kth cluster. You can think of μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ as the center of mass for cluster kkk. We will also introduce an indicator variable zn,kz_{n,k}zn,k​ where zn,k=1z_{n,k} = 1zn,k​=1 if the nthn^{th}nth data point belongs to cluster kkk and 000 otherwise. Our goal then, is to optimize our set of cluster centroids {μk}\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_k\}{μk​} and our cluster assignments zn,kz_{n, k}zn,k​ such that the sum of the squared distances from each data point to its assigned centroid is minimized. In plain language, if we are going to assign a point to a particular cluster, we would like the center of that cluster to be as close as possible to the point. We can write out this objective with the following equation J=∑n=1N∑k=1Kzn,k∥xn−μk∥22 J = \sum_{n = 1}^N\sum_{k = 1}^Kz_{n, k}\Vert\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k\Vert^2_2 J=n=1∑N​k=1∑K​zn,k​∥xn​−μk​∥22​ Our job then is to choose the values for zn,kz_{n, k}zn,k​ and μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ that minimize JJJ arg min⁡rn,k,μk∑n=1N∑k=1Kzn,k∥xn−μk∥22 \argmin_{r_{n, k}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}}\sum_{n = 1}^N\sum_{k = 1}^Kz_{n, k}\Vert\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k\Vert^2_2 rn,k​,μk​argmin​n=1∑N​k=1∑K​zn,k​∥xn​−μk​∥22​

Finding zn,jz_{n, j}zn,j​

Intuitively, the value for zn,jz_{n, j}zn,j​ that minimizes JJJ is simply the one which assigns its associated data point to the closest cluster center. More formally zn,j={1if j=arg min⁡k∥xn−μk∥220otherwise z_{n, j} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } j = \argmin_k \Vert \mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k \Vert^2_2 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} zn,j​={10​if j=argmink​∥xn​−μk​∥22​otherwise​

Finding μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​

To find the center for the jthj^{th}jth cluster we can find the value for μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​ which minimizes JJJ. We’ll start by taking its derivative with respect to μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​ ∂J∂μj=∂∂μj∑n=1N∑k=1Kzn,k∥xn−μk∥22=∂∂μj∑n=1Nzn,j∥xn−μj∥22=∂∂μj∑n=1Nzn,j(xn−μj)⊤(xn−μk)=−2∑n=1Nzn,j(xn−μj) \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial J}{\partial \boldsymbol{\mu}_j} &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j}\sum_{n = 1}^N\sum_{k = 1}^Kz_{n, k}\Vert\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k\Vert^2_2\\ &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j}\sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}\Vert\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j\Vert^2_2\\ &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j}\sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j)^\top(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k)\\ &= -2\sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j) \end{aligned} ∂μj​∂J​​=∂μj​∂​n=1∑N​k=1∑K​zn,k​∥xn​−μk​∥22​=∂μj​∂​n=1∑N​zn,j​∥xn​−μj​∥22​=∂μj​∂​n=1∑N​zn,j​(xn​−μj​)⊤(xn​−μk​)=−2n=1∑N​zn,j​(xn​−μj​)​ Now we can set the derivative equal to 000 and solve for μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​ 0=−2∑n=1Nzn,j(xn−μj)=∑n=1Nzn,jxn−zn,jμj∑n=1Nzn,jμj=∑n=1Nzn,jxnμj∑n=1Nzn,j=∑n=1Nzn,jxnμj=∑n=1Nzn,jxn∑n=1Nzn,j \begin{aligned} 0 &= -2\sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j) \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n - z_{n, j}\boldsymbol{\mu}_j \\ \sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}\boldsymbol{\mu}_j &= \sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n \\ \boldsymbol{\mu}_j \sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j} &= \sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n \\ \boldsymbol{\mu}_j &= \frac{\sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n}{\sum_{n=1}^N z_{n, j}} \end{aligned} 0n=1∑N​zn,j​μj​μj​n=1∑N​zn,j​μj​​=−2n=1∑N​zn,j​(xn​−μj​)=n=1∑N​zn,j​xn​−zn,j​μj​=n=1∑N​zn,j​xn​=n=1∑N​zn,j​xn​=∑n=1N​zn,j​∑n=1N​zn,j​xn​​​ The denominator in the above equation is the number of data points assigned to the jthj^{th}jth cluster, and so μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​ is simply the average of its assigned points.

Now notice that the equations for our two parameters each contains the other parameter as a variable. This motivates an iterative, algorithmic solution in which we optimize one parameter while fixing the other, and then optimize the second parameter holding the first one fixed. Our procedure will go like this:

KKK-means Algorithm

(1) Initialize our cluster centers μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​
(2) Compute our assignments zn,kz_{n, k}zn,k​ with our current value for μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​
(3) Using our new assignments, compute new cluster centers μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​
(4) Repeats steps (2) and (3) until changes in JJJ between steps are negligible.
Implementation

Figure 2. Iterations of the KKK-means algorithm on the rescaled Old Faithful data set
Figure 3. KKK-means objective function during fitting.

As you can see, for this dataset the algorithm converges extremely quickly and we get a decent clustering in only a few optimization steps. In practice KKK-means is often a good first choice for clustering, but the technique does have some serious drawbacks.

Perhaps the most obvious drawback is that we have no principled way of choosing the number of clusters KKK. In fact a larger number of clusters will always result in a lower value of JJJ. In our toy example this isn’t a problem, largely because our data is 2-dimensional and so we can visualize it, but if our data were to be higher dimensional than this would be more difficult. There does exist some metrics for determining the optimal cluster number, but these have their flaws as well. In addition, KKK-means can be quite sensitive to the initialization of {μk}\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_k\}{μk​}, particularly when our data is not as easily separable as our toy example. There does exist initialization strategies which help to alleviate this, but there are more problems. One is that our objective function JJJ models our clusters as equally sized spheres, an assumption which will not hold in many (maybe most) circumstances. Finally, KKK-means gives us back hard cluster assignments, when sometimes we’d like to have a confidence or probability that a data point belongs to a particular cluster.

Luckily, our next technique will allow us to address almost all of these shortcomings.

Gaussian Mixture Model

Gaussian mixture models (GMM) are a powerful probabilistic tool for solving the clustering problem that will help to ameliorate many of the problems we faced with KKK-means. A GMM is a just a linear combination of KKK Gaussian distributions where each component is weighted by some scalar πk\pi_kπk​ such that ∑k=1Kπk=1\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k = 1∑k=1K​πk​=1. This constraint allows us to interpret the combination itself as a probability distribution. We will interpret each Gaussian component as the distribution of a particular cluster. For any one data point x\mathbf{x}x the GMM says it has a probability given by p(x)=∑k=1Kπk⋅N(x∣μk,Σk) p(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k \cdot \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k) p(x)=k=1∑K​πk​⋅N(x∣μk​,Σk​) Where μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ and Σk\bold{\Sigma}_kΣk​ are the mean and covariance of the kthk^{th}kth component respectively.

Figure 4. Example GMM with two components

To start we will introduce a set of variables znz_nzn​ just like we did with KKK-means, where zn∈{1,…,K}z_n \in \{1, \dots, K\}zn​∈{1,…,K} indicates the cluster identity for the nthn^{th}nth data point. Constructing a set of unobserved variables like this is extremely common in unsupervised learning problems. Often times we refer to these zzz variables as latent variables. We said before that we interpret our mixture components as our clusters, and so we have p(z=k)=πk p(z = k) = \pi_k p(z=k)=πk​ This just means that the probability a data point comes from cluster kkk is equal to its weighting in the mixture. We can also write out the distribution of x\mathbf{x}x conditioned on the value of zzz. p(x∣z=k)=N(x∣μk,Σk) p(\mathbf{x} \mid z=k) = \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k) p(x∣z=k)=N(x∣μk​,Σk​) This is just the distribution of the kthk^{th}kth cluster.

To fit this model to our data we will rely on maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) which I wrote about in my previous post. MLE will allow us to determine the optimal values for our model parameters Θ={πk,μk,Σk}\bold{\Theta} = \{\pi_k, \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k\}Θ={πk​,μk​,Σk​}. To start we first must construct our likelihood function p({x}∣Θ)=∏n=1Np(xn) p(\{\mathbf{x}\}\mid \bold{\Theta}) = \prod_{n=1}^N p(\mathbf{x}_n) p({x}∣Θ)=n=1∏N​p(xn​) We can use the sum and product rule to decompose our likelihood into the marginal distribution over zzz and the condition distribution of x\mathbf{x}x given zzz. This is useful because we already wrote down the forms of these above. ∏n=1Np(xn)=∏n=1N∑k=1Kp(xn,z=k)=∏n=1N∑k=1Kp(z=k)p(xn∣z=k)=∏n=1N∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk) \begin{aligned} \prod_{n=1}^N p(\mathbf{x}_n) &= \prod_{n=1}^N \sum_{k=1}^K p(\mathbf{x}_n, z=k) \\ &= \prod_{n=1}^N\sum_{k=1}^K p(z=k)p(\mathbf{x}_n\mid z=k) \\ &= \prod_{n=1}^N\sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k \cdot \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k) \end{aligned} n=1∏N​p(xn​)​=n=1∏N​k=1∑K​p(xn​,z=k)=n=1∏N​k=1∑K​p(z=k)p(xn​∣z=k)=n=1∏N​k=1∑K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)​ Now we can take the log of this expression to get our log-likelihood L=log⁡p({x}∣Θ)=∑n=1Nlog⁡[∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk)] \mathcal{L} = \log p(\{\mathbf{x}\}\mid \bold{\Theta}) = \sum_{n=1}^N \log \left[ \sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k \cdot \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)\right] L=logp({x}∣Θ)=n=1∑N​log[k=1∑K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)] The MLE procedure now tells us to find the values for {πk},{μk}\{\pi_k\}, \{\boldsymbol{\mu}_k\}{πk​},{μk​} and {Σk}\{\bold{\Sigma}_k\}{Σk​} that maximize L\mathcal{L}L. First let’s find the maximum likelihood estimate for μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​.

Finding μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​

We’ll start by taking the derivative of L\mathcal{L}L with respect to μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​ ∂L∂μj=∂∂μj∑n=1Nlog⁡[∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk)]=∑n=1N∂∂μjlog⁡[∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk)] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j} &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j}\sum_{n=1}^N \log \left[ \sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k \cdot \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)\right]\\ &=\sum_{n=1}^N \frac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j} \log \left[ \sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k \cdot \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)\right] \end{aligned} ∂μj​∂L​​=∂μj​∂​n=1∑N​log[k=1∑K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)]=n=1∑N​∂μj​∂​log[k=1∑K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)]​ Here we can apply the chain rule A2 ∂L∂μj=∑n=1N∂∂μj(∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk))∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk)=∑n=1Nπj⋅N(xn∣μj,Σj)⋅Σj−1(xn−μj)∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk) \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j} &= \sum_{n=1}^N \frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial\boldsymbol{\mu}_j} \Bigl(\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)\Bigr)} {\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)} \\ &=\sum_{n=1}^N\frac{\pi_j\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_j, \bold{\Sigma}_j)\cdot\bold{\Sigma}_j^{-1}(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j)} {\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)} \end{aligned} ∂μj​∂L​​=n=1∑N​∑k=1K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)∂μj​∂​(∑k=1K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​))​=n=1∑N​∑k=1K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)πj​⋅N(xn​∣μj​,Σj​)⋅Σj−1​(xn​−μj​)​​ That last step is just another application of the chain rule, as well as equation 86 from the matrix cookbook.

Now to clean things up a bit let’s define a new parameter γn,j\gamma_{n, j}γn,j​ which we will define as γn,j=πj⋅N(xn∣μj,Σj)∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk) \gamma_{n, j} = \frac{\pi_j\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_j, \bold{\Sigma}_j)}{\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)} γn,j​=∑k=1K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)πj​⋅N(xn​∣μj​,Σj​)​ This quantity will appear a lot going forward and abstracting it this way will help us notationally, however this term also has a rich meaning: it is the conditional probability of zzz given x\mathbf{x}x. To see this we can use Bayes Rule p(zn=j∣xn)=p(zn=j)p(xn∣zn=j)∑k=1Kp(zn=k)p(xn∣zn=k)=πj⋅N(xn∣μj,Σj)∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk)=γn,j \begin{aligned} p(z_n = j \mid \mathbf{x}_n) &= \frac{p(z_n = j)p(\mathbf{x}_n \mid z_n=j)}{\sum_{k=1}^K p(z_n = k)p(\mathbf{x}_n \mid z_n = k)}\\ &=\frac{\pi_j\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_j, \bold{\Sigma}_j)}{\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k\cdot\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k)} \\ &=\gamma_{n, j} \end{aligned} p(zn​=j∣xn​)​=∑k=1K​p(zn​=k)p(xn​∣zn​=k)p(zn​=j)p(xn​∣zn​=j)​=∑k=1K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)πj​⋅N(xn​∣μj​,Σj​)​=γn,j​​ This understanding allows us to view πk\pi_kπk​ as the prior probability that zn=kz_n = kzn​=k before observing xn\mathbf{x}_nxn​, and γn,k\gamma_{n, k}γn,k​ as the posterior probability that zn=kz_n = kzn​=k after we observe xn\mathbf{x}_nxn​. γn,k\gamma_{n, k}γn,k​ is also often referred to as the responsibility because it can be viewed as the ability of the kthk^{th}kth cluster to explain the value of xn\mathbf{x}_nxn​. Also, notice that ∑k=1Kγn,k=1\sum_{k=1}^K \gamma_{n, k} = 1∑k=1K​γn,k​=1. This should make sense because in our model each data point has to come from a cluster.

Now we can plug γn,j\gamma_{n, j}γn,j​ into our derivative and set it equal to 000 to solve for μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​ 0=∑n=1Nγn,jΣj−1(xn−μj)=Σj−1∑n=1Nγn,jxn−γn,jμj∑n=1Nγn,jμj=∑n=1Nγn,jxnμj=∑n=1Nγn,jxn∑n=1Nγn,jμj=∑n=1Nγn,jxnNj \begin{aligned} 0 &= \sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j} \bold{\Sigma}_j^{-1}(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j)\\ &=\bold{\Sigma}_j^{-1} \sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n - \gamma_{n, j}\boldsymbol{\mu}_j\\ \sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j}\boldsymbol{\mu}_j &= \sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n\\ \boldsymbol{\mu}_j &= \frac{\sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n}{\sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j}}\\ \boldsymbol{\mu}_j &= \frac{\sum_{n=1}^N \gamma_{n, j}\mathbf{x}_n}{N_j}\\ \end{aligned} 0n=1∑N​γn,j​μj​μj​μj​​=n=1∑N​γn,j​Σj−1​(xn​−μj​)=Σj−1​n=1∑N​γn,j​xn​−γn,j​μj​=n=1∑N​γn,j​xn​=∑n=1N​γn,j​∑n=1N​γn,j​xn​​=Nj​∑n=1N​γn,j​xn​​​ So after all of that, we have this nice result that the center of cluster kkk is a weighted average of the data where the weights are the responsibilities or the ability of that cluster to explain the data. The denominator NjN_jNj​ is the sum of the responsibilities of the jthj^{th}jth cluster across every data point, and so you can think about it almost like the effective number of data points assigned to cluster jjj.

I will leave derivations of the maximum likelihood estimates for πj\pi_jπj​ and Σj\bold{\Sigma}_jΣj​ in the appendix, but they too have nice interpretations. Σj=1Nj∑n=1Nγn,j(xn−μj)(xn−μj)⊤πj=NjN \bold{\Sigma}_j = \frac{1}{N_j}\sum_{n=1}^N\gamma_{n, j}(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j)(\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_j)^\top\qquad \pi_j = \frac{N_j}{N} Σj​=Nj​1​n=1∑N​γn,j​(xn​−μj​)(xn​−μj​)⊤πj​=NNj​​ Like μj\boldsymbol{\mu}_jμj​, our covariance estimate is a weighted empirical covariance of the data where the weights are the responsibilities of the jthj^{th}jth cluster, whilst πj\pi_jπj​ is the effective fraction of the data assigned to cluster jjj.

Notice that, as was the case in KKK-means, our values for γn,k\gamma_{n, k}γn,k​ are dependent on our parameters, whilst our parameters are themselves dependent on γn,k\gamma_{n, k}γn,k​. Like with KKK-means, this motivates an iterative approach in which we alternate between computing the responsibilities and optimizing the parameters. The procedure will go like this:

GMM Algorithm

(1) Initialize our parameters μk,Σk,πk\boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k, \pi_kμk​,Σk​,πk​
(2) Compute responsibilities γn,k\gamma_{n, k}γn,k​
(3) Using our new responsibilities, update out parameters
(4) Repeats steps (2) and (3) until changes in L\mathcal{L}L between steps are negligible.
Implementation

Figure 2. Iterations of our GMM fitting procedure.

The GMM helps to solve many of the problems we faced with KKK-means. Being a probabalistic model means that we gain access to methods for cross validating our choice of KKK. Unlike KKK-means, increasing our number of clusters will not allow us to artbitrarily increase our log-likelihood. We also gain flexibility in the shape that our clusters can take, though we are still limited to Gaussian ellipsoids. And finally we can quantify our uncertainty for outlier data points which don’t fall cleanly into any one cluster. In terms of initialization, this is still a shortcoming of the GMM as there aren’t many principled ways to ensure good results. In practice we usually run KKK-means++ first, and use this as our cluster initializations for the GMM and this usually works well.

Beyond being two of the most popular clustering techniques, I chose to write about KKK-means and GMMs because they are often used to introduce the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm. I didn’t explicitly mention the EM algorithm in this post but briefly it is an algorithm which allows us to perform MLE with latent variable models. I hope to cover the EM algorithm in a future post when my understanding of it is better, and when I do I will link it here.

KKK-means implementation

def fit(X, K=2):

    def J(assignments, mu):
        j = 0
        for k in range(K):
            j += (np.linalg.norm(X[assignments == k] - mu[k], axis=1) ** 2).sum()
        return j
    
    def assign_clusters(mu):
        distances = np.zeros(shape=(K, len(X)))
        for k in range(K):
            distances[k] = np.linalg.norm(X - mu[k], axis=1)
        return distances.argmin(axis=0)
    
    def update_mu(assignments, mu):
        new_mu = np.zeros_like(mu)
        for k in range(K):
            new_mu[k] = X[assignments == k].mean()
        return new_mu
    
    mu_updates = []
    assignment_updates = []
    j_scores = []
    
    old_mu = np.array([[1.0, -1.5],
                       [-1.0, 1.5]])
    old_assignments = assign_clusters(old_mu)
    old_j = np.inf
    
    mu_updates.append(old_mu)
    assignment_updates.append(old_assignments)
    j_scores.append(J(old_assignments, old_mu))

    while True:

        new_mu = update_mu(old_assignments, old_mu)
        j_scores.append(J(old_assignments, new_mu))

        new_assignments = assign_clusters(new_mu)
        new_j = J(new_assignments, new_mu)
        j_scores.append(new_j)
        
        if abs(new_j - old_j) < 1e-4:
            break
        
        mu_updates.append(new_mu)
        assignment_updates.append(new_assignments)

        old_mu, old_assignments, old_j = new_mu, new_assignments, new_j
    
    return mu_updates, assignment_updates,a j_scores

Chain rule application in GMM derivation. ddxlog⁡(g(x))=g′(x)g(x) \frac{d}{dx}\log(g(x)) = \frac{g^\prime(x)}{g(x)} dxd​log(g(x))=g(x)g′(x)​ This sometimes gets called the “log-derivative trick”, which isn’t really a trick, but can be cleverly used to help compute difficult expectations. Maybe I will write a post about it one day.

A3
MLE for covariance matrices and mixture weights. ∂L∂Σj=∂∂Σj∑n=1Nlog⁡[(∑k=1Kπk⋅N(xn∣μk,Σk))] \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial \bold{\Sigma}_j} = \frac{\partial}{\partial \bold{\Sigma}_j}\sum_{n=1}^N \log \biggl[ \biggl( \sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k \cdot \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x}_n \mid \boldsymbol{\mu}_k, \bold{\Sigma}_k) \biggr) \biggr]∂Σj​∂L​=∂Σj​∂​n=1∑N​log[(k=1∑K​πk​⋅N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​))]

A4
GMM implementation

from scipy.stats import multivariate_normal
outer = np.outer
def fit_gmm(X, K=2):

    def compute_LL():
        log_probs = np.zeros((len(X), K))
        for k in range(K):
            log_probs[:, k] += multivariate_normal(mu[:, k], sigma[..., k]).pdf(X) * pi[k]
        log_probs = np.log(log_probs.sum(1))
        return log_probs.sum()
    
    def compute_gamma():
        gamma = np.zeros((len(X), K))
        for k in range(K):
            gamma[:, k] = multivariate_normal(mu[:, k], sigma[..., k]).pdf(X) * pi[k]
        gamma /= gamma.sum(axis=1, keepdims=True)
        return gamma

    def compute_Nk():
        return np.sum(gamma, axis=0)

    def compute_mu():
        mu = np.zeros((2, K))
        for k in range(K):
            mu[:, k] = (gamma[:, k, np.newaxis] * X).sum(axis=0) / N_k[k]
        return mu

    
    def compute_sigma():
        sigma = np.zeros((2, 2, K))
        for k in range(K):
            for n in range(len(X)):
                sigma[..., k] += (gamma[n, k] * outer(X[n] - mu[:, k], X[n] - mu[:, k])) / N_k[k]
        return sigma

    def compute_pi():
        return N_k / len(X)
    
    
    LLs, mus, sigmas, pis, gammas = [], [], [], [], []
    mu = np.array([[1.2, -1.5],
                   [-2.0, 1.5]])
    sigma = np.zeros((2, 2, 2))
    sigma[..., 0] = np.eye(2) * 0.1
    sigma[..., 1] = np.eye(2) * 0.1
    pi = np.array([0.5, 0.5])
    
    mus.append(mu)
    sigmas.append(sigma)
    pis.append(pi)
    
    LL_old = -np.inf
    
    while True:
        gamma = compute_gamma()
        N_k = compute_Nk()
        mu = compute_mu()
        sigma = compute_sigma()
        pi = compute_pi()
        LL_new = compute_LL()

        mus.append(mu)
        sigmas.append(sigma)
        pis.append(pi)
        gammas.append(gamma)
        LLs.append(LL_new)
        if LL_new - LL_old < 1e-9:
            gammas.append(compute_gamma())
            break
        else:
            LL_old = LL_new

    return mus, sigmas, pis, gammas, LLs
entry.summary: In machine learning, clustering encompasses a family of problems and techniques for grouping unlabeled data into categories. In contrast to classification, where our job is to learn relationships between data and their associated labels, in clustering our job is to learn the labels themselves by leveraging the patterns and structure present in the data. To make this more concrete, imagine you are given two datasets containing images of cats and dogs. The datasets are identical except that in the first dataset each image comes with a label cat or dog, and in the second you only are given the image. In classification our job is to learn what features of the image are most predictive of the label (cat ears, dog nose, etc.), whereas in clustering our job is to learn how to group similar images together without any pre-existing labels. That is, to identify clusters that correspond to cat and dog based solely on the inherent features and patterns observed in the images. The vast majority of data is unlabeled, yet the need for effective algorithmic techniques to extract meaningful information from such data is critical for its use. From the grouping of genetic sequences to identify disease patterns, to image segmentation, uses for clustering abound. In this post I introduce the problem of clustering and derive two popular techniques: KKK-means and Gaussian mixture models (GMM). To begin I will apply KKK-means to the Old Faithful dataset to give a concrete example of clustering before using the techniques shortcomings to motivate GMMs. KKK-Means The KKK-means algorithm is a simple and intuitive approach to clustering that doesn’t require any probability theory to understand. Suppose we are given some data set D\mathcal{D}D consisting of NNN Euclidean vectors. D={x1…xn…xN} \mathcal{D} = \{\mathbf{x}_1 \dots \mathbf{x}_n \dots \mathbf{x}_N\} D={x1​…xn​…xN​} In our example dataset each vector is 222-dimensional, but KKK-means still works in higher dimensions. Importantly, we have no other additional information. Unlike classification, we have no class labels to work with, only the raw coordinates of each data point. Figure 1. The normalized old faithful dataset. In the unmodified data the axes represent the duration of an eruption and the time till the next eruption for the Old Faithful geyser in Yellowstone National Park. We would like to partition the dataset above into KKK sub-groups such that each data point xn\mathbf{x}_nxn​ is associated with a unique cluster kkk. Intuitively, we would like similar data points to be clustered together and dissimilar data points to be clustered apart. It just so happens that in our dataset it is visually obvious how we should assign points to clusters, but in practice our data is rarely this nice. Our goal is essentially to categorize or classify this unlabeled data. In doing so we will depart from classification and optimize not just the boundary of the clusters, but the labels associated with each data point as well. To begin, we’ll introduce two variables. The first is a set of KKK vectors {μ1,…,μK}\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_1, \dots, \boldsymbol{\mu}_K\}{μ1​,…,μK​} where μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ is the centroid or prototype of the kthk^{th}kth cluster. You can think of μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ as the center of mass for cluster kkk. We will also introduce an indicator variable zn,kz_{n,k}zn,k​ where zn,k=1z_{n,k} = 1zn,k​=1 if the nthn^{th}nth data point belongs to cluster kkk and 000 otherwise. Our goal then, is to optimize our set of cluster centroids {μk}\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_k\}{μk​} and our cluster assignments zn,kz_{n, k}zn,k​ such that the sum of the squared distances from each data point to its assigned centroid is minimized. In plain language, if we are going to assign a point to a particular cluster, we would like the center of that cluster to be as close as possible to the point. We can write out this objective with the following equation J=∑n=1N∑k=1Kzn,k∥xn−μk∥22 J = \sum_{n = 1}^N\sum_{k = 1}^Kz_{n, k}\Vert\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k\Vert^2_2 J=n=1∑N​k=1∑K​zn,k​∥xn​−μk​∥22​ Our job then is to choose the values for zn,kz_{n, k}zn,k​ and μk\boldsymbol{\mu}_kμk​ that minimize JJJ arg min⁡rn,k,μk∑n=1N∑k=1Kzn,k∥xn−μk∥22 \argmin_{r_{n, k}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}}\sum_{n = 1}^N\sum_{k = 1}^Kz_{n, k}\Vert\mathbf{x}_n - \boldsymbol{\mu}_k\Vert^2_2 rn,k​,μk​argmin​n=1∑N​k=1∑K​zn,k​∥xn​−μk​∥22​

entry.content:
In statistics, maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) is a fundamental technique used to estimate the parameters of a probability distribution based on observed data. The mathematical formulation of MLE can be intimidating if you haven’t seen it before, but the idea motivating it is extremely simple and has deep connections to abductive reasoning, also known as inference to the best explanation. Here, I go over the basics of MLE for future posts covering its uses and extensions. To begin, let’s informally discuss a concrete example and then we’ll try to generalize what we learn from it and get more rigorous.

Note: in this post I use MLE to refer both to the technique of maximum likelihood estimation, but also to the estimate itself

Flipping Biased Coins

Imagine you are given a biased coin (a coin for which the odds of flipping heads or tails is not 50/5050/5050/50) and are tasked with approximating the probability with which it lands heads. You have nothing at your disposal, no way to directly measure the weightedness of the coin. All you can do is flip it and see the outcome. How do you go about doing this? Your intuition probably tells you to observe a bunch of coin flips and simply count the frequency of heads. Our gut tells us that for a sufficiently high number of flips this number should approach the true probability. But is there a way to reason our way there without relying purely on intuition? Let’s try.

Firstly, since we know there are only two possible outcomes we can say that if P(H)=θP(H) = \thetaP(H)=θ then it must be the case that P(T)=1−θP(T) = 1 - \thetaP(T)=1−θ. Additionally, we know that we have to observe a large number of flips before we can say much of anything about the probabilities, and we also know that these flips are all independent of one another. Let’s call the number of flips we observe nnn. Finally, if you’ve been exposed to basic probability theory you might remember that the probability of two independent events co-occuring is the product of their individual probabilities. To convince yourself of this, consider the case of flipping two fair coins. The probability of observing any one pair is 14=(12)2\frac{1}{4}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^241​=(21​)2 because we have 444 distinct outcomes, 222 for each coin A1. P(H,T)=P(H)P(T)P(H, T) = P(H)P(T)P(H,T)=P(H)P(T) With this information we can write the probability of observing a particular set of nnn coin flips which we denote as D\mathcal{D}D given a particular probability of flipping heads θ\thetaθ: P(D∣θ)=θ⋅θ⋯θ⋅θ⏞times we flip heads⋅(1−θ)(1−θ)⋯(1−θ)(1−θ)⏟times we flip tails=θk(1−θ)n−k P(\mathcal{D} \mid \theta) = \overbrace{\theta \cdot \theta \cdots \theta\cdot\theta}^{\mathclap{\text{times we flip heads}}} \cdot \underbrace{(1 - \theta)(1 - \theta)\cdots(1 - \theta)(1 - \theta)}_{\mathclap{\text{times we flip tails}}} =\theta^k(1 - \theta)^{n - k}P(D∣θ)=θ⋅θ⋯θ⋅θtimes we flip heads​⋅times we flip tails​(1−θ)(1−θ)⋯(1−θ)(1−θ)​​=θk(1−θ)n−k where kkk is the number of times we flip heads and n−kn - kn−k is the number of times we flip tails.

Now, ask yourself the following question: given some observed set of flips D\mathcal{D}D, what value for θ\thetaθ maximizes P(D)P(\mathcal{D})P(D); what value of θ\thetaθ makes our observed dataset most probable? Said another way, given a set of flip outcomes, what value for P(H)P(H)P(H) could we choose that would maximize the chances of observing those outcomes? That number is the maximum likelihood estimate. θ^MLE=arg max⁡θP(D∣θ)\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}}=\argmax_\theta{P(\mathcal{D}\mid \theta)}θ^MLE​=θargmax​P(D∣θ) At first encounter the MLE estimate can often feel slippery or circular. We are using our data to approximate a model that best explains…our data. However, MLE is really the operationalization of a deep intuition: given an outcome, what conditions would have most likely led to that outcome? The mathematical formulation may not be as intuitive, but the underlying idea is beautifully straightforward.

"At a superficial level, the idea of maximum likelihood must be prehistoric: early hunters and gatherers may not have used the words 'method of maximum likelihood' to describe their choice of where and how to hunt and gather, but it is hard to believe they would have been surprised if their method had been described in those terms."(Stigler, 2007)

If we have some data, and we are willing to assume that it comes from a particular distribution (a normal distribution, for example), along with some other things, then MLE finds what parameters to give that distribution to make it most consistent with our data. In this example we arrived at our distribution through reasoning about the flipping process, and now we are trying to find the value for its parameter θ\thetaθ which will best explain our data.

Okay, lets see MLE in action. We are tasked with solving the following optimization problem arg max⁡θP(D∣θ)=arg max⁡θ[θk(1−θ)n−k] \argmax_{\theta}P(\mathcal{D}\mid\theta) = \argmax_{\theta}\left[\theta^k(1 - \theta)^{n - k}\right]θargmax​P(D∣θ)=θargmax​[θk(1−θ)n−k] The solution to said problem will be our estimate θ^MLE≈θ\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}} \approx \thetaθ^MLE​≈θ which is the approximate probability of our biased coin flipping heads. To start we can notice that whatever argument maximizes our function will also maximize its logarithm. This is because the logarithm is a monotonically increasing function. Reframing the problem this way will allow us to get rid of those annoying exponents and turn multiplication into addition A2. arg max⁡θ[θk(1−θ)n−k]=arg max⁡θ[log⁡(θk(1−θ)n−k)]=arg max⁡θ[log⁡(θk)+log⁡((1−θ)n−k)]=arg max⁡θ[klog⁡θ+(n−k)log⁡(1−θ)]\begin{aligned} \argmax_{\theta}\left[\theta^k(1 - \theta)^{n - k}\right] &= \argmax_{\theta}\left[\log(\theta^k(1 - \theta)^{n - k})\right] \\ &= \argmax_{\theta}\left[\log(\theta^k) + \log((1-\theta)^{n-k})\right]\\ &= \argmax_{\theta}\left[k\log\theta + (n-k)\log(1-\theta)\right] \end{aligned}θargmax​[θk(1−θ)n−k]​=θargmax​[log(θk(1−θ)n−k)]=θargmax​[log(θk)+log((1−θ)n−k)]=θargmax​[klogθ+(n−k)log(1−θ)]​ So far all we have done is some algebraic manipulation of P(D∣θ)P(\mathcal{D} \mid \theta)P(D∣θ). Now to solve the optimization problem, we can take the derivative of our function and solve for its maximum by setting that equal to zero. ddθlog⁡P(D∣θ)=ddθ[klog⁡θ+(n−k)log⁡(1−θ)]=kθ−n−k1−θ \begin{aligned} \frac{d}{d\theta}\log P(\mathcal{D}\mid\theta) &= \frac{d}{d\theta}\left[k\log\theta + (n-k)\log(1-\theta)\right]\\ &=\frac{k}{\theta} - \frac{n-k}{1-\theta} \end{aligned} dθd​logP(D∣θ)​=dθd​[klogθ+(n−k)log(1−θ)]=θk​−1−θn−k​​ Now we set our equation equal to 000, replace θ\thetaθ with θ^MLE\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}}θ^MLE​, and solve. For succinctness I will write θ^MLE\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}}θ^MLE​ as θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ 0=kθ^−n−k1−θ^=k(1−θ^)θ^θ^−(n−k)(1−θ^)θ^1−θ^=k(1−θ^)−θ^(n−k)=k−kθ^−nθ^+kθ^=k−nθ^θ^MLE=kn \begin{aligned} 0 &= \frac{k}{\hat{\theta}} - \frac{n-k}{1-\hat{\theta}}\\ &=\frac{k(1-\hat{\theta})\hat{\theta}}{\hat{\theta}} - \frac{(n-k)(1-\hat{\theta})\hat{\theta}}{1-\hat{\theta}}\\ &= k(1 - \hat{\theta}) - \hat{\theta}(n - k)\\ &= k - k\hat{\theta} - n\hat{\theta} + k\hat{\theta} \\ &= k - n\hat{\theta}\\ \hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}} &= \frac{k}{n} \end{aligned} 0θ^MLE​​=θ^k​−1−θ^n−k​=θ^k(1−θ^)θ^​−1−θ^(n−k)(1−θ^)θ^​=k(1−θ^)−θ^(n−k)=k−kθ^−nθ^+kθ^=k−nθ^=nk​​ And so at the end of all of that we find that the maximum likelihood estimate for the probability of flipping heads given a dataset is simply the frequency of head occurences in our data. Our intuitions have been confirmed! That was a lot of math for such a simple answer, but granted this was a pretty simple problem. Can the MLE generalize to a larger problem space where it’s harder for our intuition to guide us? The answer is yes, but before we get there, lets simulate some coin flips and see how our estimate does as the size of our dataset increases.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
# Parameters
true_theta = 0.65   # True theta
n_flips = 1000  # Number of coin flips
trials = 50   # 50 trials of 1000 flips each
trial_outcomes = []
for trial in range(trials):
    # Simulate coin flips
    outcomes = np.random.binomial(n=1, p=true_theta, size=n_flips)  # 1 is heads, 0 is tails
    mle = np.cumsum(outcomes) / np.arange(1, n_flips + 1)
    trial_outcomes.append(mle)
# Plotting
for i, outcome in enumerate(trial_outcomes):
    if i == 0:
        plt.plot(outcome, label=r'$\frac{k}{n}$', lw=0.6)
    else:
        plt.plot(outcome, lw=0.6)
plt.axhline(y=true_theta, color='black', linestyle='--', label='True Probability of Heads')
plt.title('50 Estimates of P(H)')
plt.xlabel('Number of Coin Flips')
plt.ylabel('Cumulative Probability of Heads')
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
Figure 1. The maximum likelihood estimate computed for 50 trials with n=1000n=1000n=1000 and P(H)=0.65P(H)=0.65P(H)=0.65

In the image above, I plot the evolution of 505050 estimates of P(H)P(H)P(H) as more coin flip landings are observed and used to update the MLE. Qualitatively we can tell our intuition that “more data is better” was also correct. As nnn gets larger we see our estimates getting closer to the true value, albeit with most of the progress happening within the first 400400400 observations. In fact, although we won’t prove it here, under some basic assumptions it can be shown that in the limit, as our number of data points approaches infinity, the MLE estimate actually converges to the true value of θ\thetaθ.

Generalizing the MLE

One of the most compelling attributes of maximum likelihood estimation is its broad applicability. MLE is not limited to specific distributions or data types; it can be applied to any situation where a likelihood function can be constructed. However, in its simplest formulation (the one discussed in this post) there are some strong assumptions we have to make about our data for the technique to work well. In the remainder of this post I will go over MLE in its general formulation and highlight what those assumptions are.

We begin by observing a set of data points X1,X2,…,XnX_1, X_2, \dots, X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​ which are assumed to be independent and identical samples from a probability distribution P(X;θ)P(X; \theta)P(X;θ), where XXX represents the domain of the distribution and θ\thetaθ represents its parameters. We don’t know the value(s) of θ\thetaθ (that’s the point of MLE) but we know the class of distributions (normal, Poisson, etc.) to which PPP belongs. Ultimately what we want from MLE is a data informed approximation of θ\thetaθ which we refer to as θ^MLE\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}}θ^MLE​. Using this estimate we will be able to paramaterize a distribution which reflects our observations and which allows us to make statistical propositions about our dataset.

The first step in MLE is to construct a likelihood function L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) Ln(θ)=∏i=1nP(Xi;θ) \mathcal{L}_n(\theta) = \prod_{i=1}^n P(X_i; \theta) Ln​(θ)=i=1∏n​P(Xi​;θ) The above equation says that our likelihood function L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) is the cumulative product (A3) of our probability distribution PPP evaluated at each of our data points XiX_iXi​ for a given parameterization θ\thetaθ. The fact that the likelihood is a function over the parameters and not the data is important to note and implicit in this equation is all of the assumptions needed for MLE:

(1) Our data is comprised of independent, uncorrelated samples (hence the cumulative product)
(2) Each data point was sampled identically (PPP is unchanging across data points)
(3) We know the form of PPP, though obviously not the exact values of θ\thetaθ

But what does the likelihood function actually tell us? The likelihood function serves as a bridge between our data and our possible choices for parameters. It is a function that quantifies the ability of a particular estimate of θ\thetaθ to explain our data. If we were to choose a value for θ\thetaθ and plug it in to L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) we would get a number quantifying the plausibility of that θ\thetaθ given the observed data. Note that previously we were using the notation P(D∣θ)P(\mathcal{D}\mid\theta)P(D∣θ), but this is really the same idea. For a given value of θ\thetaθ what is the probability of our data?

To make this point more clear, let’s go back to the coin example. If we were to flip our coin 101010 times and observe that it landed on heads 888 out of those 101010, what would be the shape of L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ)? The function now looks like L(θ)=θ8(1−θ)20≤θ≤1 \mathcal{L}(\theta) = \theta^8(1-\theta)^2 \qquad 0 \leq \theta \leq 1 L(θ)=θ8(1−θ)20≤θ≤1 What does this look like plotted?

def likelihood_function(n_heads: int, n_tails: int, theta: float) -> float:
    return (theta ** n_heads) * ((1 - theta) ** n_tails)
theta_values = np.linspace(0, 1, 1000)
heads, tails = 8, 2
plt.plot((likelihood_function(heads, tails, theta_values)))
plt.xticks(np.arange(0, 1001, 100), [f'{0.1 * i:0.2f}' for i in range(11)])
plt.xlabel(r'$\theta$')
plt.ylabel(r'$\mathcal{L}(\theta)$')
plt.legend()
plt.show()
Figure 2. L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) when k=8,n=10k=8, n=10k=8,n=10

As you can see, our function is clearly maximized at θ=0.8\theta=0.8θ=0.8 exactly as expected from our work in the previous section. This is the big point of MLE. If we were to choose any value but kn\frac{k}{n}nk​ for θ\thetaθ, L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) which is the probability of our data under different choices of θ\thetaθ, would be smaller. Thus given the data (k=8,n−k=2)(k=8,\enspace n-k=2)(k=8,n−k=2) the probability of observing our data is maximized when we choose θ=θ^MLE=0.8\theta=\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}}=0.8θ=θ^MLE​=0.8

What would L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) look like for a different set of observations? If we were to have some other frequency of heads, the curve above would swing between 111 and 000 but would always have a maximum value at kn\frac{k}{n}nk​

theta_values = np.linspace(0, 1, 1000)
heads = np.arange(11)
for n_heads in heads:
    n_tails = 10 - n_heads
    likelihood = likelihood_function(n_heads, n_tails, theta_values)
    plt.plot(likelihood / np.linalg.norm(likelihood), label=fr'$k = {n_heads}$')
plt.xticks(np.arange(0, 1001, 100), [f'{0.1 * i:0.2f}' for i in range(11)])
plt.xlabel(r'$\theta$')
plt.ylabel(r'$\frac{L(\theta)}{\Vert L(\theta)\Vert_2}$')
plt.legend(ncol=2)
plt.show()
Figure 3. Diagram of the likelihood function as we sweep over values of kkk and keep nnn fixed at 101010. The function has been normalized here for visualization purposes. In reality, for k≠0,k≠10k\neq 0, k\neq 10k​=0,k​=10, the heights are much smaller.

So now if we understand that the likelihood function allows us to put a value for θ\thetaθ in and get a measure of its ability to explain our data out, it follows that if we want to find an approximation for the true θ\thetaθ we should choose the θ\thetaθ which maximizes the likelihood function.

Let’s now continue with our generalized version of MLE.

The raw likelihood function is Ln(θ)=∏i=1nP(Xi;θ)\mathcal{L}_n(\theta)=\prod_{i=1}^nP(X_i; \theta)Ln​(θ)=∏i=1n​P(Xi​;θ). In general, products are more difficult to work with than sums, both analytically and numerically, and so in practice we always work with the log-likelihood function L(θ)L(\theta)L(θ). Ln(θ)=log⁡Ln(θ)=log⁡∏i=1nP(Xi;θ)=∑i=1nlog⁡P(Xi;θ) L_n(\theta) = \log{\mathcal{L}_n(\theta)} = \log\prod_{i=1}^n P(X_i; \theta) = \sum_{i=1}^n \log{P(X_i; \theta)} Ln​(θ)=logLn​(θ)=logi=1∏n​P(Xi​;θ)=i=1∑n​logP(Xi​;θ) As was noted before, transforming the likelihood function like this does not change the θ\thetaθ which maximizes the function. Now, all that’s left to do is find the arg max⁡\argmaxargmax over θ\thetaθ. Typically this involves taking the derivative of Ln(θ)L_n(\theta)Ln​(θ) and finding the global maximum by solving for the value of θ\thetaθ that makes that equal 000. θ^MLE=arg max⁡θLn(θ)=θstddθLn(θ)=0 \begin{aligned} \hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}} &= \argmax_{\theta}{L_n(\theta)}\\ &= \theta \enspace \text{st} \enspace \frac{d}{d\theta}L_n(\theta) = 0 \end{aligned} θ^MLE​​=θargmax​Ln​(θ)=θstdθd​Ln​(θ)=0​ Depending on the specifics of the particular likelihood function this may be difficult to do analytically.

A Final Example

As a final example let’s find the maximum likelihood estimate for the Poisson distribution which has parameter λ\lambdaλ. The Poisson distribution expresses the probability of a given number of events happening in a fixed interval of time or space, and is given by P(X;λ)=λXe−λX! P(X; \lambda) = \frac{\lambda^X e^{-\lambda}}{X!} P(X;λ)=X!λXe−λ​ where kkk is the number of events and λ\lambdaλ is the mean rate of occurences in the interval. entry.summary: In statistics, maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) is a fundamental technique used to estimate the parameters of a probability distribution based on observed data. The mathematical formulation of MLE can be intimidating if you haven’t seen it before, but the idea motivating it is extremely simple and has deep connections to abductive reasoning, also known as inference to the best explanation. Here, I go over the basics of MLE for future posts covering its uses and extensions. To begin, let’s informally discuss a concrete example and then we’ll try to generalize what we learn from it and get more rigorous. Note: in this post I use MLE to refer both to the technique of maximum likelihood estimation, but also to the estimate itself Flipping Biased Coins Imagine you are given a biased coin (a coin for which the odds of flipping heads or tails is not 50/5050/5050/50) and are tasked with approximating the probability with which it lands heads. You have nothing at your disposal, no way to directly measure the weightedness of the coin. All you can do is flip it and see the outcome. How do you go about doing this? Your intuition probably tells you to observe a bunch of coin flips and simply count the frequency of heads. Our gut tells us that for a sufficiently high number of flips this number should approach the true probability. But is there a way to reason our way there without relying purely on intuition? Let’s try. Firstly, since we know there are only two possible outcomes we can say that if P(H)=θP(H) = \thetaP(H)=θ then it must be the case that P(T)=1−θP(T) = 1 - \thetaP(T)=1−θ. Additionally, we know that we have to observe a large number of flips before we can say much of anything about the probabilities, and we also know that these flips are all independent of one another. Let’s call the number of flips we observe nnn. Finally, if you’ve been exposed to basic probability theory you might remember that the probability of two independent events co-occuring is the product of their individual probabilities. To convince yourself of this, consider the case of flipping two fair coins. The probability of observing any one pair is 14=(12)2\frac{1}{4}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^241​=(21​)2 because we have 444 distinct outcomes, 222 for each coin A1. P(H,T)=P(H)P(T)P(H, T) = P(H)P(T)P(H,T)=P(H)P(T) With this information we can write the probability of observing a particular set of nnn coin flips which we denote as D\mathcal{D}D given a particular probability of flipping heads θ\thetaθ: P(D∣θ)=θ⋅θ⋯θ⋅θ⏞times we flip heads⋅(1−θ)(1−θ)⋯(1−θ)(1−θ)⏟times we flip tails=θk(1−θ)n−k P(\mathcal{D} \mid \theta) = \overbrace{\theta \cdot \theta \cdots \theta\cdot\theta}^{\mathclap{\text{times we flip heads}}} \cdot \underbrace{(1 - \theta)(1 - \theta)\cdots(1 - \theta)(1 - \theta)}_{\mathclap{\text{times we flip tails}}} =\theta^k(1 - \theta)^{n - k}P(D∣θ)=θ⋅θ⋯θ⋅θtimes we flip heads​⋅times we flip tails​(1−θ)(1−θ)⋯(1−θ)(1−θ)​​=θk(1−θ)n−k where kkk is the number of times we flip heads and n−kn - kn−k is the number of times we flip tails. Now, ask yourself the following question: given some observed set of flips D\mathcal{D}D, what value for θ\thetaθ maximizes P(D)P(\mathcal{D})P(D); what value of θ\thetaθ makes our observed dataset most probable? Said another way, given a set of flip outcomes, what value for P(H)P(H)P(H) could we choose that would maximize the chances of observing those outcomes? We are using our data to approximate a model that best explains…our data. However, MLE is really the operationalization of a deep intuition: given an outcome, what conditions would have most likely led to that outcome? The mathematical formulation may not be as intuitive, but the underlying idea is beautifully straightforward. "At a superficial level, the idea of maximum likelihood must be prehistoric: early hunters and gatherers may not have used the words 'method of maximum likelihood' to describe their choice of where and how to hunt and gather, but it is hard to believe they would have been surprised if their method had been described in those terms."(Stigler, 2007) If we have some data, and we are willing to assume that it comes from a particular distribution (a normal distribution, for example), along with some other things, then MLE finds what parameters to give that distribution to make it most consistent with our data. In this example we arrived at our distribution through reasoning about the flipping process, and now we are trying to find the value for its parameter θ\thetaθ which will best explain our data. Okay, lets see MLE in action. MLE is not limited to specific distributions or data types; it can be applied to any situation where a likelihood function can be constructed. However, in its simplest formulation (the one discussed in this post) there are some strong assumptions we have to make about our data for the technique to work well. In the remainder of this post I will go over MLE in its general formulation and highlight what those assumptions are. Ultimately what we want from MLE is a data informed approximation of θ\thetaθ which we refer to as θ^MLE\hat{\theta}_{\text{MLE}}θ^MLE​. Using this estimate we will be able to paramaterize a distribution which reflects our observations and which allows us to make statistical propositions about our dataset. The first step in MLE is to construct a likelihood function L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) Ln(θ)=∏i=1nP(Xi;θ) \mathcal{L}_n(\theta) = \prod_{i=1}^n P(X_i; \theta) Ln​(θ)=i=1∏n​P(Xi​;θ) The above equation says that our likelihood function L(θ)\mathcal{L}(\theta)L(θ) is the cumulative product (A3) of our probability distribution PPP evaluated at each of our data points XiX_iXi​ for a given parameterization θ\thetaθ.
